Astronomy is the study of the universe beyond Earth's atmosphere. It involves exploring the stars, planets, galaxies, and other celestial objects. People who study astronomy, called astronomers, use special tools like telescopes to observe the universe. They also use computers to analyze data and make predictions about the behavior of the celestial objects.

Astronomers are interested in understanding the origins of the universe, how it has changed over time, and how it is structured. They want to know what the universe is made of, how it was formed, and what its ultimate fate will be. By studying the universe, astronomers can gain insights into the laws of physics and how the universe operates. They can also learn about the potential for life on other planets and the possibility of other civilizations.

They want to understand how the universe was formed and how it has changed over time. By studying the stars and galaxies, astronomers can learn about the age and composition of the universe.

Astronomers also study the planets in our solar system. They want to know if there is life on other planets. Some planets are too hot or too cold for life to exist, but others might be just right. Astronomers are also interested in asteroids and comets, which are small rocky or icy objects that orbit the sun.
